abstract: Investigations on the synthesis of bi- or tri-metallic alloy nanoparticles have been relatively limited. Thus, we present here results of experiments to synthesize Sn-30Zn-10Cu (wt%) nanopowder alloys by chemical reduction. Characterization by electron microscopy and powder X-ray diffraction showed that nanoparticles with an average diameter of 20 nm were obtained. Microstructure and phase evolution of the as-synthesized particles upon heating were investigated and compared with the corresponding bulk alloy. The results showed that the nanoparticles contain all three constituents (i.e. Sn, Zn and Cu), possess a core-shell morphology and exhibit a phase configuration different from the bulk alloy.

author_highlights.sentence: An attempt to synthesize Sn-Zn-Cu nanoparticles by chemical reduction.
Particles exhibit a core-shell structure with Zn/ZnO on the outside.
On heating to temperatures above 300 °C, Zn2SnO4 is formed.
Formation of Zn2SnO4 proves that Sn and Zn coexist in nanoparticles.
Together with Cu-Zn phases it proves that all three elements coexist in nanoparticles.
